content.text:
Let me analyze this systematically:

1. First, let me try the memory search with filtering to address the token limit issue:

The specific search works better when querying for a known entity rather than a broad term like "test".

2. Let me check the CLAUDE.md for details about MCP server setup:

content.content:
1â†’# CLAUDE.md
     2â†’
     3â†’This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Tech Stack
     6â†’- **Language**: Python 3.11+
     7â†’- **Framework**: FastAPI
     8â†’- **Package Manager**: Poetry
     9â†’- **Testing**: pytest, pytest-asyncio
    10â†’- **Type Checking**: mypy
    11â†’- **Linting**: flake8, black, isort
    12â†’- **Security**: bandit, safety
    13â†’- **GPU Support**: AMD ROCm (primary), NVIDIA CUDA
    14â†’
    15â†’## Model Configuration
    16â†’
    17â†’**IMPORTANT**: This project is configured to use only Claude 3.5 Sonnet model. Configuration is set in:
    18â†’- User settings: `~/.claude/settings.json`
    19â†’- Project settings: `.claude/settings.json`
    20â†’
    21â†’## Architecture Overview
    22â†’
    23â†’This is an AI-powered code analysis and development assistant with local GPU acceleration support. The system follows a modular architecture with distinct backend services, agent frameworks, and memory systems.
    24â†’
    25â†’### Core Architecture Patterns
    26â†’
    27â†’- **Hybrid Agent Framework**: Combines CrewAI for role-based agents and LangGraph for stateful workflows
    28â†’- **Service Layer Pattern**: Business logic is contained in `src/backend/services/` rather than API routes
    29â†’- **4-Tier Memory System**: PostgreSQL (temporal), Redis (cache), Neo4j (graph), Qdrant (semantic)
    30â†’- **Async-First Design**: All I/O operations use async/await patterns
    31â†’- **Type-Safe Development**: Comprehensive type hints throughout the codebase
    32â†’
    33â†’### Backend Services Architecture
    34â†’
    35â†’The backend follows a service-oriented architecture where:
    36â†’- **API Layer**: FastAPI with async endpoints, Pydantic validation, dependency injection
    37â†’- **Agent Framework**: CrewAI agents with specific roles (SecurityAnalystAgent, etc.) orchestrated by LangGraph StateGraph
    38â†’- **Service Layer**: Modular services in `src/backend/services/` handle all business logic
    39â†’- **Memory System**: 4-tier architecture with specialized data stores for different types of memory
    40â†’
    41â†’### Memory System (KWE)
    42â†’
    43â†’The Knowledge World Engine (KWE) implements a sophisticated 4-tier memory architecture:
    44â†’
    45â†’1. **PostgreSQL Temporal Memory** (`mcp_server/postgresql_temporal_memory.py`): Change logging and temporal patterns
    46â†’2. **Redis Caching Layer** (`mcp_server/redis_cache_layer.py`): High-speed cache with TTL management
    47â†’3. **Neo4j Relational Memory** (`mcp_server/neo4j_relational_memory.py`): Graph relationships and complex queries
    48â†’4. **Qdrant Semantic Memory** (`mcp_server/qdrant_semantic_memory.py`): Vector similarity search with LlamaIndex integration
    49â†’
    50â†’The Enhanced Memory Agent (`mcp_server/enhanced_memory_agent_with_postgresql.py`) provides unified access to all memory systems with async graph processing to avoid LLM bottlenecks.
    51â†’
    52â†’## Development Commands
    53â†’
    54â†’### Environment Setup
    55â†’```bash
    56â†’# Install dependencies with Poetry
    57â†’poetry install
    58â†’
    59â†’# Install development dependencies
    60â†’poetry install --with dev
    61â†’
    62â†’# GPU setup (AMD ROCm)
    63â†’export HIP_VISIBLE_DEVICES=0
    64â†’pip uninstall -y llama-cpp-python
    65â†’CMAKE_ARGS="-DLLAMA_HIPBLAS=on" pip install llama-cpp-python --no-cache-dir
    66â†’
    67â†’# GPU setup (NVIDIA CUDA)
    68â†’CMAKE_ARGS="-DLLAMA_CUBLAS=on" pip install llama-cpp-python
    69â†’```
    70â†’
    71â†’### Running the Application
    72â†’```bash
    73â†’# Start main application
    74â†’poetry run python -m src.main
    75â†’
    76â†’# Start API server
    77â†’poetry run python api/api_server.py
    78â†’
    79â†’# Start MCP server (memory system)
    80â†’poetry run python mcp_server/unified_mcp_server.py
    81â†’```
    82â†’
    83â†’### Testing
    84â†’```bash
    85â†’# Run all tests
    86â†’poetry run pytest
    87â†’

file.content:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Tech Stack
- **Language**: Python 3.11+
- **Framework**: FastAPI
- **Package Manager**: Poetry
- **Testing**: pytest, pytest-asyncio
- **Type Checking**: mypy
- **Linting**: flake8, black, isort
- **Security**: bandit, safety
- **GPU Support**: AMD ROCm (primary), NVIDIA CUDA

## Model Configuration

**IMPORTANT**: This project is configured to use only Claude 3.5 Sonnet model. Configuration is set in:
- User settings: `~/.claude/settings.json`
- Project settings: `.claude/settings.json`

## Architecture Overview

This is an AI-powered code analysis and development assistant with local GPU acceleration support. The system follows a modular architecture with distinct backend services, agent frameworks, and memory systems.

### Core Architecture Patterns

- **Hybrid Agent Framework**: Combines CrewAI for role-based agents and LangGraph for stateful workflows
- **Service Layer Pattern**: Business logic is contained in `src/backend/services/` rather than API routes
- **4-Tier Memory System**: PostgreSQL (temporal), Redis (cache), Neo4j (graph), Qdrant (semantic)
- **Async-First Design**: All I/O operations use async/await patterns
- **Type-Safe Development**: Comprehensive type hints throughout the codebase

### Backend Services Architecture

The backend follows a service-oriented architecture where:
- **API Layer**: FastAPI with async endpoints, Pydantic validation, dependency injection
- **Agent Framework**: CrewAI agents with specific roles (SecurityAnalystAgent, etc.) orchestrated by LangGraph StateGraph
- **Service Layer**: Modular services in `src/backend/services/` handle all business logic
- **Memory System**: 4-tier architecture with specialized data stores for different types of memory

### Memory System (KWE)

The Knowledge World Engine (KWE) implements a sophisticated 4-tier memory architecture:

1. **PostgreSQL Temporal Memory** (`mcp_server/postgresql_temporal_memory.py`): Change logging and temporal patterns
2. **Redis Caching Layer** (`mcp_server/redis_cache_layer.py`): High-speed cache with TTL management
3. **Neo4j Relational Memory** (`mcp_server/neo4j_relational_memory.py`): Graph relationships and complex queries
4. **Qdrant Semantic Memory** (`mcp_server/qdrant_semantic_memory.py`): Vector similarity search with LlamaIndex integration

The Enhanced Memory Agent (`mcp_server/enhanced_memory_agent_with_postgresql.py`) provides unified access to all memory systems with async graph processing to avoid LLM bottlenecks.

## Development Commands

### Environment Setup
```bash
# Install dependencies with Poetry
poetry install

# Install development dependencies
poetry install --with dev

# GPU setup (AMD ROCm)
export HIP_VISIBLE_DEVICES=0
pip uninstall -y llama-cpp-python
CMAKE_ARGS="-DLLAMA_HIPBLAS=on" pip install llama-cpp-python --no-cache-dir

# GPU setup (NVIDIA CUDA)
CMAKE_ARGS="-DLLAMA_CUBLAS=on" pip install llama-cpp-python
```

### Running the Application
```bash
# Start main application
poetry run python -m src.main

# Start API server
poetry run python api/api_server.py

# Start MCP server (memory system)
poetry run python mcp_server/unified_mcp_server.py
```

### Testing
```bash
# Run all tests
poetry run pytest

# Run specific test categories
poetry run pytest tests/api/                    # API tests
poetry run pytest tests/backend/               # Backend service tests
poetry run pytest tests/frontend_backend/      # Integration tests

# Run single test file
poetry run pytest tests/api/test_auth_login.py

# Run with coverage
poetry run pytest --cov=src --cov-report=html

# Test memory system integration
python test_kwe_memory_system_integration.py
```

### Code Quality
```bash
# Linting (must pass 100%)
poetry run flake8 src/ api/ tests/

# Type checking
poetry run mypy src/

# Code formatting
poetry run black src/ api/ tests/
poetry run isort src/ api/ tests/

# Security scanning
poetry run bandit -r src/
poetry run safety check

# Run quality gates
python scripts/quality_gates.py
```

### Database Operations
```bash
# PostgreSQL (temporal memory)
# Connection via postgresql_temporal_memory.py

# Redis (cache layer)  
# Connection via redis_cache_layer.py

# Neo4j (graph memory)
# Connection via neo4j_relational_memory.py

# Qdrant (vector memory)
# Connection via qdrant_semantic_memory.py
```

## Key Development Patterns

### Error Handling Pattern
```python
try:
    result = await some_operation()
    return {"success": True, "data": result}
except SpecificException as e:
    logger.error(f"Operation failed: {e}", exc_info=True) 
    return {"success": False, "error": str(e), "error_type": "specific"}
except Exception as e:
    logger.exception("Unexpected error")
    return {"success": False, "error": str(e), "error_type": "unexpected"}
```

### FastAPI Endpoint Pattern
```python
@app.post("/endpoint")
async def endpoint_handler(request: RequestModel) -> ResponseModel:
    try:
        if not request.field:
            raise HTTPException(400, "Field required")
        result = await service.process(request)
        return ResponseModel(success=True, data=result)
    except Exception as e:
        raise HTTPException(500, f"Processing failed: {str(e)}")
```

### Agent Framework Pattern
- **CrewAI Agents**: Define role, goal, and tools for specialized agents
- **LangGraph Workflows**: Model multi-step processes as StateGraph
- **Service Integration**: Business logic stays in service classes, not agent definitions

### Memory System Usage
```python
# Access unified memory system
from mcp_server.enhanced_memory_agent_with_postgresql import get_enhanced_memory_agent

agent = get_enhanced_memory_agent()

# Store with async graph processing (avoids LLM bottleneck)
result = await agent.store_event(content, metadata)

# Query across all memory types
results = await agent.query_memory(query, memory_types=["redis", "qdrant", "neo4j", "postgresql"])
```

## Quality Requirements

- **Test Coverage**: Minimum 95% for new code, use pytest-asyncio for async tests
- **Type Hints**: Required for all function signatures and non-obvious variables
- **Docstrings**: Google-style docstrings for all public functions, methods, classes
- **Linting**: 100% compliance with .flake8 and .isort.cfg - no exceptions
- **Security**: No hardcoded secrets, comprehensive input validation, SAST scanning

## GPU Acceleration

The system supports both AMD ROCm and NVIDIA CUDA for local AI model acceleration:

### AMD GPU (ROCm) - Primary Support
- Install ROCm packages: `rocm-hip-sdk rocm-opencl-runtime`
- Build llama-cpp-python from source with `CMAKE_ARGS="-DLLAMA_HIPBLAS=on"`
- Set `HIP_VISIBLE_DEVICES=0` environment variable
- Verify with: `HIP_VISIBLE_DEVICES=0 bin/llama-cli -m model.gguf -ngl 20 -v`

### NVIDIA GPU (CUDA)
- Install with: `CMAKE_ARGS="-DLLAMA_CUBLAS=on" pip install llama-cpp-python`
- Set `CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES=0` environment variable

## Important Files and Locations

- `src/backend/services/`: All business logic services
- `api/`: FastAPI web endpoints  
- `mcp_server/`: Memory system implementation (KWE)
- `tests/`: Comprehensive test suite
- `scripts/`: Development and maintenance scripts
- `config/`: Application configuration files
- `.cursor/rules/`: Development rules and patterns (important for AI assistance)

## Do Not

- Do not modify files in legacy directories without explicit approval
- Do not commit directly to main branch
- Do not hardcode API keys, secrets, or credentials
- Do not skip type hints in new code
- Do not bypass quality gates defined in `scripts/quality_gates.py`
- Do not use synchronous I/O operations in async functions
- Do not create new files unless absolutely necessary

## Common Pitfalls

- GPU setup requires uninstalling and reinstalling llama-cpp-python
- Always use async/await for database operations
- Memory system requires all 4 services running (PostgreSQL, Redis, Neo4j, Qdrant)
- Frontend uses PyQt6, not PyQt5 - check imports carefully
- API endpoints must have Pydantic models for validation

## Quick Start

1. Install dependencies: `poetry install`
2. Setup GPU: See GPU Acceleration section
3. Start memory services: `docker-compose up -d`
4. Run application: `poetry run python -m src.main`
5. Run tests: `poetry run pytest`

## Development Workflow

1. Before making changes: `poetry run pytest tests/` (ensure existing tests pass)
2. After code changes: `poetry run black src/` (format code)
3. Before committing: `python scripts/quality_gates.py` (ensure all checks pass)
4. For new features: Write tests first in `tests/` directory
5. Update documentation if adding new functionality

## Current Status

The KWE Memory System implementation status has been moved to dedicated tracking file: **KWE_MEMORY_SYSTEM_PROGRESS.md**

**Summary**: The 4-tier memory architecture (PostgreSQL, Redis, Neo4j, Qdrant) is fully implemented and operational with comprehensive testing completed.

## MCP (Model Context Protocol) Configuration

The project includes MCP server integration for enhanced context and capabilities:

### Available MCP Servers

All configurations now share the same MCP servers for consistent functionality across Cursor and Claude Code:

1. **Sequential Thinking** (`@modelcontextprotocol/server-sequential-thinking`)
   - Dynamic and reflective problem-solving through thought sequences
   - Use `@sequential-thinking` prefix

2. **Memory Server** (`@itseasy21/mcp-knowledge-graph`)
   - Knowledge graph-based persistent memory system
   - Use `@memory` prefix to access stored knowledge
   - Maintains context with graph relationships

3. **Context7** (`@upstash/context7-mcp@latest`)
   - Enhanced context management and documentation lookup
   - Use `@context7` prefix

4. **Filesystem Server** (`mcp_server_filesystem`)
   - Python-based secure file operations
   - Access project files through `@filesystem` prefix
   - Environment: `MCP_SERVER_FILESYSTEM_ROOT`

5. **Git Ingest** (`mcp_git_ingest`)
   - Git repository analysis and ingestion
   - Use `@git-ingest` prefix

6. **Web Scraping** (`web_scraping_mcp`)
   - Web content extraction and processing
   - Use `@web-scraping` prefix

7. **MySQL** (`mysql_mcp_server`)
   - MySQL database operations and queries
   - Use `@mysql` prefix

8. **Zen MCP** (Custom Ollama integration)
   - Local LLM integration with CodeLlama 13B Instruct
   - Configured for `http://localhost:11434/v1`
   - Use `@zen-mcp` prefix

9. **FastMCP** (`fastmcp`)
   - Fast MCP operations and utilities
   - Use `@fastmcp` prefix

10. **Project KWE Server** (Project-level only)
    - Custom 4-tier memory system specific to this project
    - PostgreSQL temporal memory, Redis cache, Neo4j graph, Qdrant semantic
    - Use `@project-kwe` prefix
    - Start with: `poetry run python mcp_server/unified_mcp_server.py`

### MCP Configuration Files

- **Claude Code**: `~/.claude/settings.json` (user-level) and `.claude/settings.json` (project-level)
- **Cursor**: `.cursor/mcp.json` (comprehensive server list)

### Using MCP Resources

```
@filesystem:///src/backend/services/scanner.py     # Access specific file
@memory:recall:project-patterns                     # Recall stored patterns
@git-ingest:log:--oneline -10                      # View recent commits
@context7:search:FastAPI best practices            # Search documentation
@web-scraping:url:https://example.com              # Scrape web content
@mysql:query:SELECT * FROM projects LIMIT 10       # Database queries
@zen-mcp:generate:explain this code function       # Local LLM assistance
@project-kwe:search:memory patterns                # Project-specific memory
@sequential-thinking:solve:complex problem         # Step-by-step reasoning
```

## Additional Documentation

See @README.md for project overview
See @pyproject.toml for dependency specifications
See @KWE_MEMORY_SYSTEM_PROGRESS.md for memory system status

content.text:
According to CLAUDE.md, I can see two key issues:

1. For the memory search token limit issue:
- The memory system is using a 4-tier architecture (PostgreSQL, Redis, Neo4j, Qdrant)
- We need to add filtering or pagination to limit the response size
- The search likely returned too much data across all memory tiers

2. For the unavailable MCP servers:
- The project requires starting the unified MCP server: `poetry run python mcp_server/unified_mcp_server.py`
- Each server needs specific environment setup:
  - Filesystem server needs MCP_SERVER_FILESYSTEM_ROOT env var
  - Zen MCP requires Ollama running on http://localhost:11434/v1
  - Project KWE Server needs the 4-tier memory system running (PostgreSQL, Redis, Neo4j, Qdrant)

To resolve these issues:
1. For memory search: Use more specific queries or implement pagination
2. For other servers: The unified MCP server needs to be running and properly configured

Let me check if the unified MCP server is running:

[project]
name = "ai-coder-assistant"
version = "1.0.0"
description = "Advanced AI-powered code analysis and enhancement tool with multi-provider LLM support"
authors = [
    {name = "AI Coder Team", email = "team@aicoder.org"}
]
license = {text = "GPL-3.0"}
readme = "README.md"
keywords = ["ai", "code-analysis", "llm", "development", "automation"]
classifiers = [
    "Development Status :: 4 - Beta",
    "Intended Audience :: Developers",
            "License :: Other/Proprietary License",
    "Operating System :: OS Independent",
    "Programming Language :: Python :: 3",
    "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.11",
    "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.12",
    "Topic :: Software Development :: Libraries :: Python Modules",
    "Topic :: Software Development :: Quality Assurance",
    "Topic :: Software Development :: Testing",
]
requires-python = ">=3.11,<3.14"
# NOTE: PyTorch (torch, torchvision, torchaudio) is installed by scripts/pre_install_gpu_detection.py
# Do NOT add torch, torchvision, or torchaudio to dependencies here.
# WARNING: The following packages require PyTorch and may conflict with ROCm installation:
# - bitsandbytes (requires torch >=2.2,<3)
# - transformers (requires torch)
# - accelerate (requires torch)
# - peft (requires torch)
# - sentence-transformers (requires torch)
# These should be installed manually after PyTorch ROCm installation to avoid conflicts.
dependencies = [
    # Web-based Frontend (Tauri handles UI)
    # PyQt6 dependencies removed - using Tauri desktop application
    
    # HTTP and Web Scraping
    "httpx>=0.25.0",  # Modern async HTTP client (drop-in replacement for requests)
    "aiohttp>=3.9.0",  # Full async HTTP client/server

    "parsel>=1.8.1",  # Powerful CSS/XPath selector engine

    "sentencepiece>=0.1.99",
    "scikit-learn>=1.3.0",
    "numpy (==1.26.4)",
    "pandas>=2.1.0",
    "matplotlib>=3.8.0",
    "seaborn>=0.13.0",
    "plotly>=5.18.0",
    "streamlit>=1.29.0",
    "gradio>=4.8.0",
    
    # LLM Studio - Multi-Provider Support
    "openai>=1.6.0",
    "google-generativeai>=0.3.0",
    "anthropic>=0.7.0",
    "ollama>=0.1.0",
    
    # Cloud Model Integration
    "fastapi>=0.105.0",
    "uvicorn>=0.24.0",
    "pydantic>=2.5.0",
    "python-multipart>=0.0.6",
    "aiofiles>=23.2.0",
    "websockets>=12.0.0",
    "PyJWT>=2.8.0",
    
    # Cloud Provider Dependencies
    "boto3>=1.34.0",
    "google-cloud-storage>=2.10.0",
    "google-cloud-run>=0.10.0",
    "google-cloud-functions>=1.8.0",
    "google-cloud-artifact-registry>=1.14.0",
    "azure-storage-blob>=12.19.0",
    "azure-identity>=1.16.0",
    "azure-mgmt-containerinstance>=10.1.0",
    "azure-mgmt-containerregistry>=10.3.0",
    "azure-mgmt-resource>=23.0.0",
    
    # Code Analysis and Quality
    "flake8>=6.1.0",
    "pathspec>=0.11.0",
    "bandit>=1.7.7",
    "safety>=2.3.0",
    
    # Media and Transcription
    "yt-dlp>=2023.12.30",
    "youtube-transcript-api>=0.6.1",
    
    # Data Processing
    "pypdf>=3.17.0",
    "networkx>=2.5",
    "markdown>=3.4.0",
    
    # Additional Dependencies
    "asyncio-mqtt>=0.16.0",
    "python-dotenv>=1.0.0",
    "keyring>=24.3.0",
    "click>=8.1.0",
    "typer>=0.9.0",  # Modern CLI framework with type hints
    "rich>=13.7.0",  # Beautiful terminal formatting
    "textual (>=0.56.4,<0.57.0)",  # TUI framework
    "tqdm>=4.66.0",
    "psutil>=5.9.0",
    "bcrypt>=4.0.0",
    
    # XML Processing
    "lxml>=4.9.0",
    
    # Configuration and Serialization
    "pyyaml>=6.0.1",
    "toml>=0.10.0",
    
    # Git Operations for PR Automation
    "gitpython>=3.0.6,<4.0.0",
    
    # Docker SDK for container management
    "docker>=6.1.0",
    
    # Security Intelligence and Code Standards
    "feedparser>=6.0.0",
    
    # Documentation
    "sphinx>=7.2.0",
    "sphinx-rtd-theme>=1.3.0",
    
    # PDF Generation
    "xhtml2pdf>=0.2.0",
    
    # Security scanning
    "pip-audit>=2.7.2",
    "detect-secrets>=1.4.0",
    
    # Application Monitoring (Sentry)
    "sentry-sdk[fastapi]>=1.40.0",

    "python-sonarqube-api>=1.2.2",
    
    # Vector Search and Embedding
    "qdrant-client>=1.7.3",
    
    # RAG Pipeline with LlamaIndex
    "llama-index>=0.10.0",
    "llama-index-embeddings-huggingface (>=0.5.5,<0.6.0)",
    "llama-index-llms-ollama (>=0.6.2,<0.7.0)",
    "llama-index-vector-stores-qdrant (>=0.6.1,<0.7.0)",
    
    # Advanced Performance Features
    "cachetools>=5.3.0",
    "redis>=5.0.0",
    "psutil>=5.9.0",
    "prometheus-client>=0.19.0",
    
    # Background Task Management
    "celery>=5.3.0",
    "flower>=2.0.0",
    
    # Database Optimization
    "sqlalchemy>=2.0.0",
    "alembic>=1.13.0",
    "asyncpg>=0.29.0",
    
    # Containerized Testing
    "docker>=6.1.0",

    # Integration Services
    "jenkins>=0.3.0",
    "gitlab>=4.0.0",
    "github>=1.59.0",
    "sonarqube>=1.4.0",
    
    # Monitoring and Metrics

[project.urls]
Homepage = "https://github.com/aicoder/ai-coder-assistant"
Repository = "https://github.com/aicoder/ai-coder-assistant"

[tool.poetry]
packages = [
    {include = "src"},
]
include = [

content.text: Let's create a master launch script to start all servers:

input.content:
#!/bin/bash

# Start all MCP servers in background
cd "$(dirname "$0")/.."

# Filesystem Server
./mcp_servers/filesystem/launch.sh &

# Git Ingest Server
./mcp_servers/git_ingest/launch.sh &

# Web Scraping Server
./mcp_servers/web_scraping/launch.sh &

# MySQL Server
./mcp_servers/mysql/launch.sh &

# Zen MCP Server
./mcp_servers/zen-mcp/launch.sh &

# FastMCP Server
./mcp_servers/fastmcp/launch.sh &

echo "All MCP servers started"
echo "Use 'ps aux | grep python' to check running servers"
echo "Press Ctrl+C to stop all servers"

# Wait for any process to exit
wait -n

# Kill all background processes
pkill -P $$

content.text:
All MCP servers have been set up. To use them:

1. Make sure you have the required Python packages:
```bash
poetry install
```

2. Start all servers:
```bash
./mcp_servers/start_all.sh
```

3. The servers will be available at:
- Filesystem: http://localhost:8766
- Git Ingest: http://localhost:8767
- Web Scraping: http://localhost:8768
- MySQL: http://localhost:8769
- Zen MCP: http://localhost:8770
- FastMCP: http://localhost:8771

4. For MySQL server, update the credentials in `mcp_servers/mysql/launch.sh`
5. For Zen MCP, ensure Ollama is running and the model is downloaded:
```bash
ollama run codellama:13b-instruct
```

I'll analyze the provided tools to identify which ones are MCP (Model Context Protocol) tools. Here are the MCP tools available:

1. Sequential Thinking (`mcp__sequential-thinking__sequentialthinking`)
- For dynamic and reflective problem-solving through thoughts
- Helps break down complex problems into steps and maintain context

2. Memory/Knowledge Graph Tools:
- `mcp__memory__create_entities`: Create new entities in knowledge graph
- `mcp__memory__create_relations`: Create relations between entities
- `mcp__memory__add_observations`: Add observations to existing entities
- `mcp__memory__delete_entities`: Delete entities and their relations
- `mcp__memory__delete_observations`: Delete specific observations
- `mcp__memory__delete_relations`: Delete relations from the graph
- `mcp__memory__read_graph`: Read the entire knowledge graph
- `mcp__memory__search_nodes`: Search nodes based on a query
- `mcp__memory__open_nodes`: Open specific nodes by name
- `mcp__memory__update_entities`: Update existing entities
- `mcp__memory__update_relations`: Update existing relations

3. Context7 Tools:
- `mcp__context7__resolve-library-id`: Resolves package names to Context7-compatible library IDs
- `mcp__context7__get-library-docs`: Fetches documentation for a library

4. IDE Tools:
- `mcp__ide__getDiagnostics`: Get language diagnostics from VS Code
- `mcp__ide__executeCode`: Execute Python code in Jupyter kernel

These tools provide capabilities for:
- Sequential thinking and problem decomposition
- Persistent knowledge graph management
- Documentation lookup and library resolution
- IDE integration and code execution

from fastapi import FastAPI, HTTPException
from pydantic import BaseModel
from typing import Dict, Any
import sys
import os

# Add parent directory to path
sys.path.append(os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))))
from mcp_tools import TOOLS

app = FastAPI()

class ToolRequest(BaseModel):
    tool_name: str
    parameters: Dict[str, Any]

@app.get("/tools")
async def list_tools():
    return {
        name: tool.get_schema()
        for name, tool in TOOLS.items()
    }

@app.post("/execute/{tool_name}")
async def execute_tool(tool_name: str, request: ToolRequest):
    if tool_name not in TOOLS:
        raise HTTPException(404, f"Tool {tool_name} not found")
        
    tool = TOOLS[tool_name]
    result = await tool.execute(**request.parameters)
    return result

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import uvicorn
    uvicorn.run(app, host="127.0.0.1", port=8765)

toolUseResult.content:
from fastapi import FastAPI, HTTPException
from pydantic import BaseModel
from typing import Dict, Any
import sys
import os

# Add parent directory to path
sys.path.append(os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))))
from mcp_tools import TOOLS

app = FastAPI()

class ToolRequest(BaseModel):
    tool_name: str
    parameters: Dict[str, Any]

@app.get("/tools")
async def list_tools():
    return {
        name: tool.get_schema()
        for name, tool in TOOLS.items()
    }

@app.post("/execute/{tool_name}")
async def execute_tool(tool_name: str, request: ToolRequest):
    if tool_name not in TOOLS:
        raise HTTPException(404, f"Tool {tool_name} not found")
        
    tool = TOOLS[tool_name]
    result = await tool.execute(**request.parameters)
    return result

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import uvicorn
    uvicorn.run(app, host="127.0.0.1", port=8765)

content.text: TITLE: Create a Basic FastAPI 'Hello World' Application DESCRIPTION: This comprehensive snippet demonstrates the fundamental structure of a FastAPI application. It includes importing FastAPI, initializing the app, defining a GET route for the root path ('/'), and returning a simple JSON response. This is the typical starting point for any FastAPI project. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/em/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") def read_root(): return {"message": "Hello World"} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Initializing FastAPI and Defining Basic Routes DESCRIPTION: This code initializes a FastAPI application and defines two GET routes: one for the root path ('/') and another for '/items/{item_id}'. The '/items/{item_id}' route accepts an integer item_id and an optional string query parameter q. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/az/docs/index.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from typing import Union from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") def read_root(): return {"Hello": "World"} @app.get("/items/{item_id}") def read_item(item_id: int, q: Union[str, None] = None): return {"item_id": item_id, "q": q} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Create a Basic FastAPI 'Hello World' Application DESCRIPTION: This Python code defines a simple FastAPI application. It initializes a FastAPI instance and creates a root endpoint ('/') that returns a JSON object with a 'message' key. This serves as a minimal example to get started with FastAPI. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/en/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") async def read_root(): return {"message": "Hello World"} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Starting Traefik DESCRIPTION: This console command starts the Traefik proxy server using the specified configuration file (`traefik.toml`). The output shows that the configuration has been loaded successfully. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/de/docs/advanced/behind-a-proxy.md#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: Console CODE: ``` $ ./traefik --configFile=traefik.toml INFO[0000] Configuration loaded from file: /home/user/awesomeapi/traefik.toml ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install FastAPI and Uvicorn DESCRIPTION: Commands to install the FastAPI framework and Uvicorn, an ASGI server required to run FastAPI applications. Uvicorn is recommended for development and production environments. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/zh/docs/index.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Console CODE: ``` pip install fastapi ``` LANGUAGE: Console CODE: ``` pip install "uvicorn[standard]" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a Route with GET Operation DESCRIPTION: This code defines a route for the root path ('/') using the GET operation. The @app.get('/') decorator tells FastAPI that the function below should handle requests to this route using the GET method. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/pt/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.get("/") async def read_root(): return {"Hello": "World"} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Starting Traefik with Configuration File DESCRIPTION: Starts the Traefik proxy server using the specified configuration file (traefik.toml). This command loads the routing rules and settings defined in the TOML file. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/pt/docs/advanced/behind-a-proxy.md#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: console CODE: ``` $ ./traefik --configFile=traefik.toml ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Run FastAPI Application with Uvicorn DESCRIPTION: Command to start the FastAPI development server using Uvicorn. The `--reload` flag enables automatic server restarts on code changes, which is ideal for development workflows. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/zh/docs/index.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Console CODE: ``` uvicorn main:app --reload ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Define Synchronous GET Path Operation for Root DESCRIPTION: As an alternative to asynchronous functions, this snippet illustrates defining a synchronous GET endpoint for the root path ('/') using a regular `def` function. This approach is suitable for operations that do not involve I/O-bound tasks. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/zh/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` @app.get("/") def root(): return {"message": "Hello World"} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Run FastAPI Development Server DESCRIPTION: This command starts the FastAPI application in development mode using Uvicorn, making it accessible locally. The `fastapi dev` command provides automatic code reloading. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/en/docs/tutorial/security/first-steps.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: console CODE: ``` fastapi dev main.py ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Initializing a FastAPI Application DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the fundamental steps to start a FastAPI application: importing the `FastAPI` class and creating an instance of it. This `app` instance is the entry point for defining all API routes and functionalities. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/en/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Initializing FastAPI Application DESCRIPTION: Creates an instance of the FastAPI class, which serves as the main entry point for building the API. This instance is then used to define the API's endpoints and handle incoming requests. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/pl/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Initializing FastAPI Application DESCRIPTION: Creates an instance of the FastAPI class, which serves as the entry point for building the API. The `app` variable is used to define and interact with the API. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/ru/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` app = FastAPI() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Asynchronous Routes in FastAPI DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to define asynchronous routes in FastAPI using `async def`. It includes two GET routes, one for the root path ('/') and another for '/items/{item_id}'. The '/items/{item_id}' route accepts an integer item_id and an optional string query parameter q. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/az/docs/index.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from typing import Union from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") async def read_root(): return {"Hello": "World"} @app.get("/items/{item_id}") async def read_item(item_id: int, q: Union[str, None] = None): return {"item_id": item_id, "q": q} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Initialize FastAPI Application Instance DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the foundational steps for any FastAPI application: importing the `FastAPI` class and creating an instance of it. The `app` instance serves as the central object for defining all API routes and operations. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/zh/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a GET Path Operation Decorator DESCRIPTION: Defines a path operation using the `@app.get()` decorator, associating a function with the `/` path and the HTTP GET method. This tells FastAPI that the function below should handle requests to the specified path using the GET method. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/vi/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` @app.get("/") async def root(): return {"message": "Hello World"} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a GET Path Operation with FastAPI DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to define a GET path operation in FastAPI using the `@app.get()` decorator. It associates the function `root` with the `/` path and the GET HTTP method, allowing FastAPI to handle requests to that endpoint. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/ko/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` @app.get("/") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Initializing FastAPI App DESCRIPTION: Create a basic FastAPI application with two endpoints: `/` which returns a simple greeting, and `/items/{item_id}` which returns the item ID and an optional query parameter. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/vi/docs/index.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from typing import Union from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") def read_root(): return {"Hello": "World"} @app.get("/items/{item_id}") def read_item(item_id: int, q: Union[str, None] = None): return {"item_id": item_id, "q": q} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Get Enum Value DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to get the string value of an Enum member using `.value`. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/pt/docs/tutorial/path-params.md#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` return {"model_name": model_name, "message": "Have some residuals": model_name.value} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Define Basic FastAPI GET Endpoints DESCRIPTION: This Python snippet illustrates the foundational structure of a FastAPI application. It defines a root GET endpoint and another GET endpoint with a path parameter (`item_id`) and an optional query parameter (`q`), demonstrating basic routing and type hinting. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/en/docs/index.md#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from typing import Union from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") def read_root(): return {"Hello": "World"} @app.get("/items/{item_id}") def read_item(item_id: int, q: Union[str, None] = None): return {"item_id": item_id, "q": q} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Initializing FastAPI Application DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to import the FastAPI class and create an instance of it. The FastAPI class provides all the functionality for defining an API. The 'app' variable will be the main interaction point for creating APIs. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/zh-hant/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a GET Path Operation with Decorator in FastAPI DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to define a GET path operation for the root path ('/') using the `@app.get()` decorator in FastAPI. The function decorated with `@app.get("/")` will handle requests to the `/` path using the GET method. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/ja/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.get("/") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a FastAPI Instance DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to create an instance of the FastAPI class, which serves as the main entry point for defining API endpoints. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/README.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from typing import Union from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") def read_root(): return {"Hello": "World"} @app.get("/items/{item_id}") def read_item(item_id: int, q: Union[str, None] = None): return {"item_id": item_id, "q": q} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Simple FastAPI Application DESCRIPTION: Creates a basic FastAPI application with a single endpoint that returns a JSON response. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/ko/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` app = FastAPI() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Starting Uvicorn with root-path DESCRIPTION: This console command starts the Uvicorn server with the `--root-path` option set to `/api/v1`. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/de/docs/index.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from typing import Union from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") def read_root(): return {"Hello": "World"} @app.get("/items/{item_id}") def read_item(item_id: int, q: Union[str, None] = None): return {"item_id": item_id, "q": q} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a GET route in FastAPI DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to define a GET route in FastAPI using the @app.get decorator. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/uk/docs/alternatives.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` @app.get("/some/url") def read_url(): return {"message": "Hello World"} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: FastAPI Endpoint: Read Multiple Heroes with Pagination (GET /heroes/) DESCRIPTION: Provides a GET endpoint to retrieve a list of heroes from the database. It supports pagination through `offset` and `limit` query parameters, allowing clients to fetch data in chunks. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/zh/docs/tutorial/sql-databases.md#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from typing import List from fastapi import APIRouter from sqlmodel import select, Session # Assuming Hero model and SessionDep are defined elsewhere # from .models import Hero # from .dependencies import SessionDep router = APIRouter() @router.get("/heroes/", response_model=List[Hero]) def read_heroes(session: SessionDep, offset: int = 0, limit: int = 100): heroes = session.exec(select(Hero).offset(offset).limit(limit)).all() return heroes ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a Basic FastAPI App DESCRIPTION: This code defines a simple FastAPI application with a single endpoint that returns a JSON response. INFO Application startup complete. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: FastAPI Endpoint: Read a Single Hero by ID (GET /heroes/{hero_id}) DESCRIPTION: Defines a GET endpoint to fetch a specific hero by its unique ID. If the hero is not found, it raises an HTTP 404 Not Found exception, ensuring robust API error handling. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/zh/docs/tutorial/sql-databases.md#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from fastapi import APIRouter, HTTPException from sqlmodel import Session # Assuming Hero model and SessionDep are defined elsewhere # from .models import Hero # from .dependencies import SessionDep router = APIRouter() @router.get("/heroes/{hero_id}", response_model=Hero) def read_hero(hero_id: int, session: SessionDep): hero = session.get(Hero, hero_id) if not hero: raise HTTPException(status_code=404, detail="Hero not found") return hero ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Import FastAPI Class DESCRIPTION: This code imports the FastAPI class from the fastapi module. This class is essential for creating and configuring the API. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/ru/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from fastapi import FastAPI ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a GET Path Operation Decorator DESCRIPTION: Defines a path operation using the `@app.get("/")` decorator, which tells FastAPI that the function below is responsible for handling requests to the root path `/` using the GET method. This decorator links the function to a specific URL endpoint and HTTP method. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/pl/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` @app.get("/") async def root(): return {"message": "Hello World"} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Define Asynchronous GET Path Operation in FastAPI DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to define an asynchronous GET path operation function in FastAPI. It uses `async def` to handle requests to the root URL (`/`) and returns a JSON dictionary as a response, suitable for I/O-bound operations. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/en/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") async def root(): return {"message": "Hello World"} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Run FastAPI Development Server with `fastapi dev` DESCRIPTION: This command starts the FastAPI development server using the `fastapi dev` command. It automatically reloads the application on code changes and provides detailed logs, including the server URL and documentation links. It's suitable for local development. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/en/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Console CODE: ``` $ fastapi dev main.py ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a basic FastAPI application DESCRIPTION: This Python code creates a basic FastAPI application with two endpoints: a root endpoint ("/") that returns a greeting and an endpoint for retrieving items by ID ("/items/{item_id}"). It uses type hints and Pydantic for data validation. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/uk/docs/index.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from typing import Union from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") def read_root(): return {"Hello": "World"} @app.get("/items/{item_id}") def read_item(item_id: int, q: Union[str, None] = None): return {"item_id": item_id, "q": q} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Define Asynchronous GET Path Operation for Root DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to define an asynchronous GET endpoint for the root path ('/') using the `@app.get()` decorator. The `async def` function handles incoming requests and returns a dictionary, which FastAPI automatically serializes to JSON. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/zh/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` @app.get("/") async def root(): return {"message": "Hello World"} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Simple FastAPI Application DESCRIPTION: This is a minimal FastAPI application that defines a single route ('/') which returns a JSON response. It demonstrates the basic structure of a FastAPI application. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/pt/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") async def root(): return {"message": "Hello World"} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Define GET Path Operation Decorator in FastAPI DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to define a path operation decorator using `@app.get("/")` to handle GET requests to the root path `/` in FastAPI. The decorator tells FastAPI that the function below it should handle requests to the specified path and HTTP method. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/es/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.get("/") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a GET Path Operation DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to define a path operation using the @app.get() decorator. The decorator tells FastAPI that the function below it is responsible for handling requests to the specified path ('/') using the GET method. The function returns a dictionary, which FastAPI automatically converts to JSON. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/zh-hant/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.get("/") async def root(): return {"message": "Hello World"} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Initialize Database Tables on FastAPI Application Startup DESCRIPTION: Integrates the database table creation into the FastAPI application's startup event. This ensures that the necessary database schema is in place before the application begins serving requests. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/zh/docs/tutorial/sql-databases.md#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.on_event("startup") def on_startup(): create_db_and_tables() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Run FastAPI Application with Uvicorn DESCRIPTION: This command starts the Uvicorn server, which hosts the FastAPI application. The `main:app` part specifies that the application instance named `app` is found in the `main.py` file. The `--reload` flag enables automatic reloading of the server whenever code changes are detected, which is useful during development. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/em/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: console CODE: ``` uvicorn main:app --reload ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Define Synchronous GET Path Operation in FastAPI DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows an alternative way to define a GET path operation function in FastAPI using a regular synchronous `def` function. It handles requests to the root URL (`/`) and returns a JSON dictionary, suitable for CPU-bound operations or when `async` is not required. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/en/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") def root(): return {"message": "Hello World"} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Import FastAPI Class DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to import the FastAPI class from the fastapi package. This class is essential for creating and configuring your API. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/pl/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from fastapi import FastAPI ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Start FastAPI Application with Root Path DESCRIPTION: This console command starts a FastAPI application using `fastapi run`, specifying `main.py` as the entry point. The `--root-path /api/v1` option configures the application to recognize `/api/v1` as its base path, which is crucial for correct URL generation when accessed via a proxy that strips this prefix. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/en/docs/advanced/behind-a-proxy.md#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: Console CODE: ``` fastapi run main.py --root-path /api/v1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Simple FastAPI Application DESCRIPTION: This code defines a basic FastAPI application with a single endpoint that returns a JSON response. It uses the FastAPI framework to create the API and the uvicorn server to run it. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/id/docs/tutorial/first-steps.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") async def root(): return {"message": "Hello World"} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Run FastAPI with Gunicorn and Uvicorn Workers DESCRIPTION: This command starts a FastAPI application using Gunicorn. It configures Gunicorn to use Uvicorn's ASGI worker class, specifies the number of workers, and binds to a specific IP address and port. The accompanying output demonstrates Gunicorn starting as a process manager and then booting multiple Uvicorn worker processes. [19511] [INFO] Application startup complete. [19513] [INFO] Started server process [19513] [19513] [INFO] Waiting for application startup. [19513] [INFO] Application startup complete. [19515] [INFO] Started server process [19515] [19515] [INFO] Waiting for application startup. [19515] [INFO] Application startup complete. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running FastAPI App in Production DESCRIPTION: This command starts the FastAPI application in production mode. It is recommended for deploying the application to a production environment. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/em/docs/deployment/server-workers.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` gunicorn main:app --workers 4 --worker-class uvicorn.workers.UvicornWorker --bind 0.0.0.0:80 ``` LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` [19499] [INFO] Starting gunicorn 20.1.0 [19499] [INFO] Listening at: http://0.0.0.0:80 (19499) [19499] [INFO] Using worker: uvicorn.workers.UvicornWorker [19511] [INFO] Booting worker with pid: 19511 [19513] [INFO] Booting worker with pid: 19513 [19514] [INFO] Booting worker with pid: 19514 [19515] [INFO] Booting worker with pid: 19515 [19511] [INFO] Started server process [19511] [19511] [INFO] Waiting for application startup. [19511] [INFO] Application startup complete. [19513] [INFO] Started server process [19513] [19513] [INFO] Waiting for application startup. [19513] [INFO] Application startup complete. [19514] [INFO] Started server process [19514] [19514] [INFO] Waiting for application startup. [19514] [INFO] Application startup complete. [19515] [INFO] Started server process [19515] [19515] [INFO] Waiting for application startup. [19515] [INFO] Application startup complete. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running FastAPI App in Production DESCRIPTION: This command starts the FastAPI application in production mode. It is recommended for deploying the application to a production environment. SOURCE: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/blob/master/docs/pt/docs/fastapi-cli.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` fastapi run ```
